metadata.case_name: Appellant Sugar Factories v. Union of India

facts.text: Appellants are three public limited companies having factories in Haryana State manufacturing and selling sugar.

Central Government required sugar factories including appellants to sell 60% of their production during 1970-71 at prices fixed by it, price for Haryana zone being Rs. 124.63 per quintal under Sugar Price Determination Order, 1971 made under s. 3(3C) of Essential Commodities Act, 1955.
Appellants filed writ petitions in Delhi High Court for quashing the Sugar Price Determination Order, 1971 and for direction to refix ex-factory price for 1970-71.
High Court dismissed writ petitions on January 10, 1972; appeals by certificate.

History of sugar control: Central Sugar Cane Act, 1934 fixed minimum cane price; Sugarcane Control Order, 1955 fixed minimum cane price considering cost of production, return from alternative crops, fair price to consumer.
Sugar control imposed 1942 under Sugar and Sugar Products Control Order, 1942; decontrolled December 8, 1947; reimposed 1949 with ex-factory price Rs. 76.35/quintal for D-24 grade.
1950: 90% production free sale; later modified to 95% of average production of preceding two years as basic quota, half excess free sale.
Control relaxed 1952-53 except small portion at controlled prices; April 1954 requisitioned 25% stock.
1958: Tariff Commission examined cost structure, constructed four zonal cost schedules based on duration and recovery percentage.

Sugar Enquiry Commission (1965) recommended five zones, cost schedules based on minimum cane price, cess/tax, commission, transport, driage, packing, grade differential, selling expenses; 12% return on capital employed.
1966-67 worst year due to drought; production fell; partial control announced August 1967: 60% levy, 40% free sale; s.3(3C) enacted.
Tariff Commission 1968-69: fresh cost schedules for 22 zones; for Haryana, conversion charges Rs.19.58/quintal; uniform return Rs.10.50/quintal equivalent to 12.5% on zonal average capital.
Ex-factory price for Haryana 1966-67: Rs.128.69/quintal (cane Rs.89.73, conversion Rs.26.46, return/rehab Rs.12.50).
Government accepted Tariff Commission recommendations except rehabilitation (deferred Feb 20, 1970).
Government fixed price Rs.124.63/quintal for Haryana 1970-71 on Jan 8, 1971.

High Court ordered Government to disclose basis; additional affidavit Sept 14, 1971: price Rs.126.93 considering purchase tax increase, wages etc.; used actual recovery 8.76%, duration 187 days for 1969-70.
Free sugar sold 1969-70: Rs.126.21-138.01; Oct 1970-May 1971: Rs.132.30-151.38; appellants sold at avg Rs.138.63.
Appellants claimed cost Rs.129.42 + additional Rs.9.51 = Rs.138.93; loss Rs.3 lacs on 65,741 quintals levy sugar.
High Court added Rs.3.22 (wages, depreciation, packing, tax) to make Rs.127.85.
Haryana purchase tax increased 24 to 50 paise/quintal cane from April 1, 1970.
Indian Sugar Mills Association represented for additional return due to high 1969-70 production; Tariff Commission suggested increase for interest on accumulated stock.
Haryana factories 1970-71: production 82,756 tonnes; despatches levy 63,741 qtls @124.63 avg; free 70,650 qtls @136.49 avg upto May 24, 1971; avg realisation Rs.130.77.
Actual duration 162 days, recovery 8.69%; cost per schedule Rs.126.61 + additions Rs.7.18 = Rs.133.79, but deducting disputed Rs.130.13; avg realisation Rs.130.77.

legal_issues.text: What is the true interpretation of s. 3(3C) of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955?
Whether the price of Rs. 124.63 per quintal was in accordance with the provisions of s. 3(3C)?

petitioner_arguments.text: Sub-sec 3C deals with levy sugar only; cl(d) means reasonable return on capital employed for production of levy sugar only, not entire production.
Price Rs.124.63 does not cover actual cost of production for 1970-71, causing loss; claims additional costs like interest Rs.2.29, freight 0.63, etc., total cost Rs.138.93.
Interpreting cl(d) as return on whole business would negate partial control scheme, allow arbitrary low levy price cushioned by free sugar profits.

respondent_arguments.text: Price determined under s.3(3C) is for entire production, ensuring reasonable return on capital employed in whole business of manufacturing sugar; based on Tariff Commission cost schedules.
Rs.124.63 based on data: Rs.126.93 adjusted for tax, wages etc.; actuals show reasonable return when levy and free sugar considered together; avg realisation Rs.130.77 vs cost Rs.130.13.

court_reasoning.text: S.3(3C) requires price determination having regard to (a) minimum cane price, (b) manufacturing cost, (c) duty/tax, (d) reasonable return on capital employed in business of manufacturing sugar (whole business, not levy only); based on zonal cost schedules for entire production.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction between 'amount payable' for levy sugar and 'price of sugar' determined for entire production.

court_reasoning.text: Historical background: cost schedules always for entire production; partial control leaves 40% free to incentivize higher cane purchase and expansion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fair price harmonizes interests of cane grower, manufacturer, consumer.

court_reasoning.text: Rejects unit-wise fixation or levy-only return as it rewards inefficiency; reasonable return Rs.10.50/quintal on zonal average capital.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Price not actual cost of every unit but for reasonably efficient representative cross-section.

court_reasoning.text: Rs.124.63 consistent with s.3(3C): Tariff Commission ex-works Rs.128.69 minus rehab Rs.2=126.69; govt Rs.126.93; High Court Rs.127.85; actual cost Rs.130.13 but avg realisation Rs.130.77 including free sugar; reasonable return obtained on whole.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No loss when entire picture considered; additional claims like interest not sustainable as production declined, stocks cleared.

holdings.text: True construction of s.3(3C): price fixed for entire sugar production ensuring reasonable return on capital employed in whole manufacturing business.
Price of Rs.124.63 per quintal for Haryana zone in 1970-71 is in accordance with s.3(3C).

statutes_cited.name: Essential Commodities Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers control over sugar, requires sale of levy sugar at price determined under s.3(3C) having regard to minimum cane price, manufacturing cost, duty/tax, reasonable return on capital.

statutes_cited.name: Sugar and Sugar Products Control Order, 1942
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulated production, distribution, prices of sugar.

statutes_cited.name: Sugar Control Order, 1963
statutes_cited.relevance: Fixed ex-factory prices for regions, regulated distribution.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed; impugned Sugar Price Determination Order, 1971 upheld as price Rs.124.63 consistent with s.3(3C); parties bear own costs throughout; liberty for directions on bank guarantees.
outcome.costs: Parties to bear their own costs throughout.

key_quotes.text: "the price to be determined by the Central Government is to be the rate at which the amount payable to the producer of such of his stock as is required to be sold is to be calculated."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes 'amount payable' for levy from 'price of sugar' for entire production.

key_quotes.text: "a reasonable return on the capital employed in the business of manufacturing sugar, which must mean the business as a whole and not the business of manufacturing levy sugar only"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on interpretation of cl.(d) of s.3(3C).

key_quotes.text: "A fair price would not thus mean the actual cost and return of every individual unit... because it would be rewarding the inefficient and the uneconomic."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains basis for zonal averaging over unit-wise costs.

key_quotes.text: "taking the picture as a whole the Haryana factories got in any event a reasonable return on the capital employed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies Rs.124.63 as fair when levy and free sales combined.
